title: Quantifying Source Speaker Leakage in One-to-One Voice Conversion
author: Scott Wellington (University of Bath), Xuechen Liu (National Institute of Informatics), Junichi Yamagishi (National Institute of Informatics), ...
relevance_why: This paper addresses information leakage in voice conversion systems, relevant to audio privacy concerns that Haohe Liu may encounter in audio synthesis and machine learning tasks.
background: Voice conversion systems aim to convert a speaker's voice to sound like another, while this study evaluates how much information about the source speaker can be inferred from the converted voice.
contribution: This paper introduces a method to quantify the leakage of source speaker information in voice conversion, achieving a solid understanding of privacy risks associated with synthetic voice outputs.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods lacked a systematic approach to quantify the privacy implications of voice conversion and primarily focused on perceptual similarity between converted and targeted voices.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by employing Earth Mover's Distance to measure the similarity of cosine similarity distributions that indicate information leakage.

key_innovation: The integration of Earth Mover's Distance in measuring source speaker leakage offers a novel quantitative framework, moving beyond subjective evaluations.
real_world_impact: The findings emphasize the necessity for voice conversion systems to enhance privacy measures, informing the development of more secure audio technologies.
limitations: The study acknowledges potential biases due to using a single vocoder model, which may affect generalizability.

new_terms.Earth Mover's Distance: **Earth Mover's Distance (EMD)** is a measure of the distance between two probability distributions over a region; it quantifies the minimum cost of transforming one distribution into another.
new_terms.cosine distance: **Cosine distance** measures the cosine of the angle between two vectors, used to determine similarity between embeddings in machine learning.
